ground_truth: He looks down from the window at Barnes and Taylor. The Mayor waves to the crowd, then steps back from the lectern to welcome President Ashton with a handshake. Barnes sees an open window. A muzzle flash illuminates the window, and the President reels back before falling. Taylor yells to a stunned Barnes. Barnes looks back up. A bearded young man dashes to the podium. Barnes tackles him. Barnes stares down at the recumbent President. Taylor helps carry the President away. The President is loaded into an ambulance. The bearded young man. They lead him off. An exasperated look on his face, Holden turns away. They loop up on hearing the distant explosion. Barnes sees the man in the checked shirt. He runs to him and grabs his camera. Barnes points. They rewind the camera in vision. Both men stare at the LCD screen. Flames and black smoke rise into the air. The smoke clears. Barnes is lying on the ground. He regains consciousness. There is a scratch on his grubby face. Barnes hauls himself to his knees. Barnes struggles to get to his feet. There are small fires all around. A man throws a blanket over a woman whose clothes are in flames. Barnes takes in the number of people lying injured. Barnes recalls the muzzle flashes in the window. Across the plaza, Matthews, clutching a chest wound, tries to sit up. Barnes runs across to him, past the mess of twisted metal crowd control barriers. Barnes bends down. Holden staggers over. Matthews falls still. Holden shakes his head. Barnes stares at his fallen colleague. Holden looks up to see the Spanish bearded cop with a gun. Holden chases after the bearded man who has holstered his gun. Barnes looks up as a GNN cameraman runs past. Barnes reads the GNN logo and leaps to his feet. He runs to the GNN outside broadcast van and enters the gallery. Barnes stares at the bank of monitors. The director watches him. Barnes sees a still frame of him being shot. Barnes searches for the cell phone. Rex watches as Barnes keys in numbers on his cell phone. He speaks into his cuff mike. He dials a number. The PA whispers into her cellphone. Barnes' eyes are fixed on the monitor. Karen glances around and manually rewinds the tape control. Barnes looks intently at the screen, his eyes unblinking. Barnes turns and runs out of the van. The events rewind. Barnes turning to Mathews. The explosion, the shooting. Taylor at Barnes' hotel door. The time on the digital clock moves to midday. The bearded man, Enrique, a handsome man in his 30s wearing a light open shirt over a dark tee shirt and with a bag over his shoulder, marches past the protestors on his way to the plaza.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He casts his gaze downward from the window, directing his attention to the bustling scene unfolding at the intersection of Barnes and Taylor. The Mayor, with a dignified air, waves cordially to the gathered crowd below, then carefully steps back from the prominent lectern, ready to extend a warm welcome to President Ashton with a firm handshake. Barnes observes an open window across the way. Suddenly, a startling muzzle flash momentarily illuminates the aperture, and the President reels backward as if struck, ultimately falling. Taylor urgently yells to a visibly stunned Barnes, who then looks back upward. A young man with a noticeable beard swiftly dashes toward the podium, full of intent. Barnes does not hesitate; he tackles the man to the ground with determination. Barnes then directs his gaze downward at the recumbent figure of the President. Taylor, without delay, steps in to assist in carrying the President away to safety. The President is quickly loaded into an awaiting ambulance. The bearded young man, apprehended, is led away by authorities. With an exasperated look etched upon his face, Holden turns his attention elsewhere. An audible explosion in the distance catches their attention, prompting all to look up. Barnes spots a man clad in a distinctive checked shirt. Barnes sprints toward him, seizing the man’s camera with urgency. He points emphatically, guiding the man to rewind the camera’s footage. Both men intently gaze at the LCD screen, captivated by the unfolding imagery. Flames and thick, black smoke begin rising ominously into the air. Once the smoke has cleared, we find Barnes lying prone on the ground, having regained consciousness. There is a noticeable scratch marking his otherwise grubby face. With effort, Barnes hauls himself up onto his knees, struggling against the chaos. He fights to get to his feet, surrounded by small fires scattered all around him. Nearby, a man throws a protective blanket over a woman whose clothing is aflame. Barnes takes a moment to comprehend the sheer number of people lying injured around him. He recalls the chilling muzzle flashes he witnessed in the window. Across the plaza, Matthews, clutching a wound in his chest, makes a desperate attempt to sit up. Barnes, propelled by urgency, runs across to him, navigating through the disarray of twisted metal and toppled crowd control barriers. As Barnes bends down, Holden staggers over to join him. Matthews falls still, unmoving. Holden, with a somber shake of his head, indicates the gravity of the situation. Barnes stands, transfixed, staring at his fallen colleague. Holden, as he raises his head, spots a Spanish bearded officer wielding a gun. Without further hesitation, Holden gives chase after the bearded man who has holstered his firearm. Barnes’ attention shifts as a GNN cameraman swiftly runs past him. Recognizing the GNN logo, Barnes leaps to his feet. He makes a dash toward the GNN outside broadcast van and hurriedly enters the gallery. Barnes stares intensely at the array of monitors in front of him. The director, sensing the gravity of the situation, watches him closely. Barnes zeroes in on a still frame showing the moment he was shot. He hurriedly searches for his cell phone. Rex observes as Barnes punches in numbers on his phone with quick precision. Speaking into his cuff mike, Barnes dials a number urgently. The PA, discreetly, whispers into her own cellphone. Barnes' eyes remain unwaveringly fixed on the monitor, absorbing every detail. Karen, with a cautious glance around, manually rewinds the tape control. Barnes watches the screen intently, his eyes never blinking. Instinctively, Barnes spins around and rushes out of the van. The sequence of events begins to rewind in his mind. Barnes turning toward Mathews. The explosion, the deafening sound of the shooting. The moment when Taylor knocks at Barnes' hotel door. The digital clock's display advances, indicating the time moving forward to midday. The bearded man, Enrique, a strikingly handsome figure in his 30s, distinctively dressed in a light open shirt layered over a dark tee shirt and carrying a bag nonchalantly over his shoulder, strides purposefully past the sea of protestors on his determined path toward the plaza.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He glances down from the window at the busy scene unfolding at Barnes and Taylor, taking in the activity below. The Mayor confidently waves to the enthusiastic crowd gathered around, a gesture that captures the moment's significance, before he steps back from the lectern with a practiced grace, turning to extend a welcoming handshake to President Ashton. Barnes's eyes catch on an open window in the nearby building, and in an instant, a bright muzzle flash lights up that very window, immediately followed by President Ashton reeling backward, the sudden force pushing him off balance until he collapses to the ground. Taylor's urgent shout jolts Barnes from his stunned state, and he quickly shifts his focus upward again. At that moment, a bearded young man makes a rapid dash towards the podium, prompting Barnes to spring into action; he lunges forward and tackles the man to the ground, ensuring he is subdued. With adrenaline still pumping, Barnes finds himself gazing down at the now recumbent President, processing the gravity of the situation before Taylor steps in, assisting with carrying the President away to safety. The urgency culminates as the President is then carefully loaded into an awaiting ambulance, while the bearded young man is apprehended and led away by authorities. In the midst of the chaos, Holden, exhibiting an exasperated demeanor, turns away from the scene. An unexpected loud explosion echoes in the distance, causing everyone, including Barnes, to instinctively look up. In the midst of this commotion, Barnes spots a man wearing a distinctive checked shirt and rushes over to him, seizing his camera. With urgency, Barnes gestures for the man to rewind the footage on the camera, both men intently staring at the LCD screen as it plays back. The screen displays a terrifying scene where flames and thick, black smoke billow upward into the sky, and as the smoke gradually dissipates, Barnes finds himself lying on the debris-laden ground. Regaining consciousness, he notices a painful scratch marking his dirt-streaked face, and with considerable effort, Barnes hauls himself up first onto his knees and then struggles laboriously to his feet. All around him, small fires stubbornly burn, casting a hellish glow, while a nearby man throws a life-saving blanket over a woman whose clothes have caught fire. As he surveys the devastation, Barnes is struck by the sobering number of people lying injured, and a flashback to the muzzle flashes in the window sears through his mind. Across the plaza, Barnes notices Matthews clutching his chest, wounded but determinedly attempting to sit up. Barnes races over to him, maneuvering through the mangled chaos of twisted metal barriers intended for crowd control. Reaching Matthews, Barnes bends down to offer assistance, just as Holden arrives, staggering over to the scene. But before any help can be given, Matthews succumbs to his injuries and falls still, prompting a sorrowful shake of Holden’s head. Barnes finds himself staring, grief-stricken, at his fallen colleague, a poignant moment interrupted when Holden’s gaze catches the movement of a Spanish bearded cop with a gun. Holden takes off in pursuit of the man as he holsters his weapon, leaving Barnes to look up just in time to see a GNN cameraman sprinting past. Reading the prominent GNN logo, Barnes is galvanized into action, leaping to his feet with renewed purpose. He darts towards the GNN outside broadcast van, barging into the gallery filled with equipment and monitors. Inside, Barnes’s eyes lock onto the bank of monitors, while the director observes him with a measured gaze. Amidst the visuals on the screens, Barnes identifies a still frame capturing the moment he was shot, escalating his urgency to search for his cell phone. As he locates the device, Rex watches closely, observing Barnes as he deliberately keys in numbers on his phone, simultaneously speaking into his cuff mike, creating a dual line of communication. He swiftly dials another number while a nearby PA discreetly whispers into her cellphone, and all the while, Barnes’s intense focus remains fixed on the monitor. Karen, sensing the tension, manually rewinds the tape control, allowing Barnes to fixate intently on the screen, his eyes transfixed and unblinking. Suddenly, Barnes pivots, propelled by a sudden realization, and dashes out of the van. As events rewind in his mind, he vividly recalls turning to Mathews, the explosion reverberating, and the shooting sequence. His memory travels back to Taylor at Barnes’ hotel door, the digital clock on the wall progressing to midday, and then the bearded man, Enrique, a striking figure in his 30s donning a light open shirt layered over a dark tee, strides with purpose past the assemblage of protestors, his bag slung over his shoulder, making his determined way to the plaza.

A window opens, and a muzzle flash signals the President being shot, causing him to collapse. Taylor shouts to a stunned Barnes, who then tackles a bearded young man rushing to the podium. As Taylor and others carry the President to an ambulance, the assailant is escorted away. Holden turns away in frustration, alerted by a distant explosion. Barnes sees a man in a checked shirt, seizes his camera, and both review footage showing flames and smoke. As the smoke clears, Barnes regains consciousness amidst small fires and injured people. He remembers the muzzle flash and notices Matthews, wounded and struggling. Barnes rushes to Matthews but watches him fall still as Holden arrives. Noticing a bearded cop with a gun, Holden pursues him while Barnes runs to the GNN broadcast van. Inside, Barnes scans the monitors, sees a still of the shooting, and uses his phone to communicate urgently. Karen rewinds the footage as Barnes intently watches the screen before sprinting out of the van. Events replay in his mind, including the explosion and shooting, as the story rewinds to Enrique, a handsome, bearded man in his 30s, approaching the plaza past protestors.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He looks down from the window at Barnes and Taylor, two undercover agents tasked with ensuring security at the event. The Mayor, a popular figure known for his community projects, waves to the crowd, then steps back from the lectern to welcome President Ashton, the nation's youngest elected leader in decades, with a handshake. Barnes, a seasoned agent, sees an open window across the street in the building known for housing antiques. A muzzle flash, indicative of a gunshot, illuminates the window, and the President reels back before falling, an eerie silence gripping the plaza. Taylor, known for his quick thinking under pressure, yells to a stunned Barnes. Barnes looks back up just as a bearded young man, later identified as an activist with ties to local protests, dashes to the podium. Barnes tackles him with the precision of years in the force. Barnes stares down at the recumbent President, his training kicking in amidst the chaos. Taylor helps carry the President away, weaving through the shocked crowd. The President is loaded into an ambulance, its sirens soon wailing through the city streets. The bearded young man, restrained now by security, is led away, confusion and anger etched on his face. An exasperated look on his face, Holden, a journalist with a keen nose for breaking news, turns away from the scene. They loop up, alerted by the distant explosion from a parked vehicle, now engulfed in flames. Barnes sees the man in the checked shirt, a known journalist from the local news station. He runs to him and grabs his camera, an older model with a large recording capacity. Barnes points, urgency in his voice. They rewind the camera in vision, a feature utilized for instant playback. Both men stare at the LCD screen, watching as flames and black smoke, a telltale sign of an incendiary device, rise into the air. The smoke clears, revealing the aftermath. Barnes is lying on the ground, debris scattered around him. He regains consciousness, groggy and disoriented, a scratch marking his dirt-streaked face. Barnes hauls himself to his knees, the ground rough beneath him. Barnes struggles to get to his feet, his legs shaky. There are small fires all around, the aftermath of the explosion. A man, a passerby moved by instinct, throws a blanket over a woman whose clothes are in flames, a heroic act amidst the chaos. Barnes takes in the number of people lying injured, the scale of the attack evident. Barnes recalls the muzzle flashes in the window, his training connecting the dots. Across the plaza, Matthews, a colleague in plainclothes, clutching a chest wound from the earlier gunfire, tries to sit up. Barnes runs across to him, dodging past the mess of twisted metal crowd control barriers, haphazard from the panic. Barnes bends down to assist. Holden, pale and shaken, staggers over, his camera still rolling. Matthews falls still, his breathing shallow. Holden shakes his head, a gesture of helplessness. Barnes stares at his fallen colleague, the weight of the day's events heavy on him. Holden looks up to see the Spanish bearded cop, rumored to be working undercover, with a gun now holstered. Holden chases after the bearded man, determination in his stride. Barnes looks up as a GNN cameraman, recognizable by his network's iconic blue vest, runs past. Barnes reads the GNN logo and leaps to his feet, a surge of realization hitting him. He runs to the GNN outside broadcast van and enters the gallery, the hub of live transmission. Barnes stares at the bank of monitors, a mosaic of live feeds. The director watches him, aware of the unfolding drama. Barnes sees a still frame of him being shot, a haunting image frozen in time. Barnes searches for the cell phone, his mind racing with options. Rex, a technician known for his expertise in crisis situations, watches as Barnes keys in numbers on his cell phone, the device a lifeline. He speaks into his cuff mike, a tool for discreet communication. He dials a number, urgency in his movements. The PA, a calm figure amidst the chaos, whispers into her cellphone, coordinating the next steps. Barnes' eyes are fixed on the monitor, scanning for details. Karen, the technical assistant, glances around and manually rewinds the tape control, her fingers deftly working. Barnes looks intently at the screen, his eyes unblinking, absorbing every detail. Barnes turns and runs out of the van, determination etched on his face. The events rewind in his mind: Barnes turning to Matthews, the explosion, the shooting, each event seared into his memory. Taylor at Barnes' hotel door, their last conversation replaying. The time on the digital clock moves to midday, the timestamp of tragedy. The bearded man, revealed to be Enrique, a handsome man in his 30s wearing a light open shirt over a dark tee shirt and with a bag over his shoulder, marches past the protestors on his way to the plaza, his steps purposeful and unyielding.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Barnes observes Mayor welcoming President Ashton, who is then shot. A bearded young man rushes the podium, and Barnes tackles him. President Ashton is taken to an ambulance. A distant explosion is heard, and Barnes finds a cameraman to review footage of the chaos. Regaining consciousness amidst fires, Barnes tries to assist the injured, including Matthews, but Matthews succumbs to his wounds. Holden pursues a bearded cop wielding a gun while Barnes heads to a GNN van. There, he sees footage of himself being shot and urgently rewinds the events. The scene rewinds to Enrique, a man in his 30s, heading to the plaza with a bag, passing protestors.
